reviewText: COLD PREY is a Norwegian slasher film that fails to bring anything new to the genre. I agree with previous comments by other reviewers who noted that something was lost due to the sub-titles, (it is a dubbed foreign film). For example, the explanation concerning the background of the killer is compromised as English viewers were unable to read the Norwegian newspaper headlines. The film also stumbled as it took a while to get rolling. Once the killing began, there were still a few of those obligatory, "why did they do that?" scenes, which detract from the credibility of the story. On the plus side though, there was some decent character development. Nonetheless, my biggest complaint is that the film lacked both gore and especially inventive kills. Gore and Inventive kill scenes carry the day in this genre and BOTH were conspicuously absent. I can even do without the splatter, had the "execution" (pun intended) of the carnage been more imaginative. When neither are present, you have a recipe for disaster, regardless of how well a job the film did in other departments. Another reviewer commented that it was as if COLD PREY wished not to offend anyone, thereby avoiding "gore alley" so to speak. Seems so. Although COLD PREY features fine cinematography, a competent score plus a good cast who played it straight; I still caught myself watching the clock. Caution: Spoiler ahead...The obligatory female lead knocking off the bad guy only works a few times then the novelty of it wears off unless there is one helluva script, (which was lacking). I also doubt that the (small utility knife?) would have significantly punctured the sub-arctic outer wear of the killer to inflict the incapacitating wound suggested. This scene was not credible. There was also a flashback "twist" featured at the end that I am still grappling with. Another marginal, formulaic outing, however, it was punctuated with some nice production values which are almost always lacking in such films. In the final analysis, there is nothing new here and the film was definitely not "scary" in my opinion. Of possible interest to die hard slasher film fans and horror film newbies.

reviewText: Four stars may seem a little generous, but this IS an entertaining entry in the "Slasher Horror" category from Norway. Originally called Fritt Vilt from 2006, it had enough success (mainly in Europe) to bankroll a sequel, aptly named Fritt Vilt II in 2008, which I have not seen, but hear is even better.There has been a mild resurgence in the slasher genre made so popular in the 80's over the last couple of years (Hatchet, immediately springs to mind as one viewers in the US would remember recently). But watching several from around the World, few bring anything new to the table, and even though Cold Prey falls into that group, it seems more watchable. Five good looking young friends go skiing, but the regular slopes are too crowded and they venture out into "wilder territory". Why wait for a ski lift when you can have an entire mountain to yourself? Everything goes great until one of the guys falls badly and breaks his leg.Shunning common sense they decide to hold up in an old abandoned ski lodge in the middle of nowhere, to tend to the boys broken limb, and there the terror begins, as of course the lodge only "appears" to be abandoned.This picture treads the same ground as most other movies of the genre from this point filled with clichés, and familiar situations to allow the hidden slasher to begin the body count at his/her/its leisure.What does work in this picture (and why I gave 4 stars) are good character development and a sharp script. As the viewer you actually begin to care about the five friends, unlike in years gone by when slasher movie actors were unknowns and like wooden cutouts, roaming around for no other reason than fodder to showcase a grisly demise.This aspect lends real tension to a lot of the scary scenes, and if you can forget about every picture that has retread this ground in the past, you will probably enjoy it.
summary: Trying to breathe new life into the slasher movie.

reviewText: Looking for the 'ultimate thrill,' a group of snowboarders head to a rarely traveled part of the mountain to face a more extreme slope. When one of the friends crashes and severely breaks his leg, the group is forced to seek shelter in an abandoned ski lodge. There, they uncover some secrets of the long-lost lodge and begin to fall victim to a pick-axe-wielding psychopath who seems more than a bit unwelcoming.While the Norwegians haven't ever been known as a real 'powerhouse' in the horror industry, they have been making a name for themselves lately with a couple strong showings in the genre. One of these is the snowy thriller 'Fritt Vilt' aka 'Cold Prey.' While the title may sound like Chinglish for the British alt-rock band, don't let that distract you from what is otherwise quite a scary little modern horror. The film starts out well with some truly breathtaking mountain scenery and well shot snowboard action. Moving from the wide expanse of the mountain terrain, the fine direction & cinematography head indoors to capture the creepy interior of the mountain lodge. Utilizing the typical "abandoned" look along with some not-so-typical emeents (like the charred remains of one room), the resort manages to be chillingly decrepit and strikingly beautiful at the same time. Regardless of the great visuals, a film like this does need more to work well. Luckily, it manages to work in those other areas, too. First, the story is pretty strong. It kind of felt like a sequel to 'The Shining' in which a group of kids head to the now-closed Overlook and reap the ghostly vengeance of Jack Torrance. Actually, that seems like an idea Hollywood would actually try, so let's forget that. Back to this movie. . . the acting is good, but not great, and some of their fear is completely unconvincing. The writing, while spotty in the dialogue on occasion, flows well ad is never boring. But, the most important element to a horror like this should always be scares, and 'Cold Prey' has 'em. With a nice mixture of jump scares, creep-outs, and suspense, this Norwegian slasher is actually quite frightening at parts and well worth the look. Overall, it is a worthy addition to the genre and should act as a great flick for those long, dark winter nights.Final verdict: 7/10.-AP3-

reviewText: I first heard about Cold Prey a couple of years ago when it was released in Norway but wrote it off because of the whole snowboarding angle which didn't sound too interesting as a plot. Something about extreme sports doesn't hold my interest so it was easy to forget the movie for the three years since its release. Cut from 2006 the films original release date to 2009 and a combination of two things have happened. One there was sequel released last year that in the grand tradition of any slasher film has been getting weaker reviews for the first for replacing dread and suspense with gore and action. And two I finally read the reviews for the original Cold Prey which greatly piqued my interest in seeing it as American horror outside of certain independents has degenerated into a wasteland of remakes it seems.Not that Cold Prey is original in itself by any means. In fact it is your basic slasher film where a masked killer stalks and kills a group of young people who have wandered into his layer, that being an abandoned lodge on top of a mountain. The group as it is decides to go snowboarding which turns bad when on wipes out beautifully injuring his leg and stranding them on the mountain looking for help. They decide to stay the night at a seemingly abandoned lodge, uncaring of the fact that theres a whole lot of provisions lying around as well as a working gas generator. And slowly but surely a large man dressed in cold weather gear stalks them and butchers them with a pick axe.Everything here goes by its formula. Theres a backstory for the villain which to me was kind of murky involving some childhood trauma. The victims fit into their roles- the sensitive girl, the sex starved couple, the comic relief. And at the end of the day its about one thing only isolating the hero to face the villain.But dont' think I'm writing this off. The major thing I think Cold Prey has going for it is the work of director Roar Uthag and the people behind the camera. Everything looks beautiful in cold blue light. The lodge is both dark and shadowy with equally painfully bright areas. Theres one shot in particular that is amazing where the heroine is fleeing in the dark and the villain just looms out of the dark of the background to hit her.  And the killer himself seems to be shot from the chest on never letting the full body be seen. I also don't know how much of this was shot on location compared to a set but what is practical on the mountain the snow is amazingly good. Maybe because I'm a fan of John Carpenters The Thing or just read Dan Simmons The Terror but this reminds that one of the most underused locations for horror is some fleeting snowbound tenement.In the end Cold Prey isn't the best horror film ever made. Its not the most original movie ever made. But in this era where American horror seems to be nothing but remakes and looking for the perfect foreign horror is spotty at best, a fun exercise in the genre thats entertaining is an easy recommendation to me.The DVD you'll get should you take that is nicely stocked with features. Theres an alternate ending presented in storyboard form since it was never shot. A making of featurette. A blooper real and two short films round out the package. With a great sound and video package retailed on a disc I found for nine dollars at my local retailer I can say that this is one DVD that won't disappoint those who like the film.

reviewText: I must admit I find too often that horror movies today are overly cliche, robbing so many themes from previous films.  And... the word "homage" is used too often where the word "unoriginal" is more befitting.  The next thing I hate is the rush to add more gore when really that tends to provide less plot or poor acting.  I usually only find two or three horror movies a year that keep my attention and/or surprise me.  Here I have to confess - I really thought this movie was going to be bad.  I was only given a small snippet of summary and the box cover to judge this movie.  Once I realized that the movie was about a killer that stalks snow-boarders, I rolled my eyes.  Then once I received it I realized that the movie was a foreign film.  This second part actually didn't hurt my feelings on the movie, but I really thought this was going to be a bad film... with subtitles too.  Well I was wrong.This movie actually is much better that I would've expected.  The actors are unknown, but that gives the movie more of a Texas Chainsaw Massacre sort of appeal to it.  As far as it being a foreign film (Norwegian), this was never a major issue.  If you didn't mind watching Pan's Labyrinth, Night Watch, High Tension, Brotherhood of the Wolf, The Orphange, etc. - then you won't mind this being subtitled either.  I really think that European horror is progressing nicely.  The movie High Tension in particular clued me into this a few years ago.  We all know that the Asian horror scene has ballooned over the last decade and now it appears that Europe may begin to hit their stride too.  And don't forget those non-subtitled ones too... British films such as The Descent, 28 Days Later, etc. have shown that production quality can be Grade A without being USA.As for this film, the movie being Norwegian should not affect your concentration.  Once the movie gets going, the suspense made me forget that I was reading the screen (which during tense moments has little to zero dialog, letting me focus in on the action).  If you appreciate slasher films that aren't just stereotypical hollywood remakes, then you should try this out.
summary: Low Expectations Before Viewing, High Hopes for More Euro-Horror After

reviewText: This DVD is packed with excellent bonus features, a real insight into how films are made. More on that in a moment.As slasher films go, this one is pretty darn good. There is an intelligence here that I've not seen in more mainstream American slasher films. The typical US film would have some not so bright teenagers completely drunk in a place they have no business being. And they one by one get killed, except for the one smart one (oh this is evil, but maybe a bit of natural selection?).The contrast here, this is 5 fairly smart people that go skiing. They are Vikings, they live in a very cold country, they grew up outdoors in the cold in the mountains, and they know how to survive. It's important to remember these are Norwegians, it is a bit hard to forget given the Norwegian dialog with subtitles. It is not unusual in any European mountain area for people to go off in remote areas and ski.When Morten breaks his leg after a fair amount of skiing, it wouldn't be unusual to look for a hut, and not turn back for the car. It's also not unusual in Europe to have cell phone reception on top of incredibly remote mountains (I know that is hard for Americans to believe, but reception is everywhere in Europe, even remote mountains). If you stay down this path of reasoning, this film never jumps the shark, what happens is not out of the realm of possibilities. Nobody in this group does something that the viewer would say, oh no you bone head, don't do that. Well except maybe Mikal leaving Ingunn in that room alone, and the small room scene with the turned over dresser (the killer should have had his axe there - but then the movie would have ended with everyone dead - right).These characters seem to respond in mostly logical ways to what happens. Jannicke and Eirik are the McGyvers of the group, and that is completely believable given the set up during the car trip. Cold Prey worked for me.The sound is absolutely incredible in this film. As with any horror film, sound is an essential element. The sound editor did an amazing job with the surround channels, crystal clear sound movement, and excellent sound stage for the voices. The subwoofer gets a fantastic workout in this film, pictures on the wall rattled in my house. There are just enough sound surprises to keep this film moving.Filming was generally very good. Most shots were sharp, properly exposed, and the CG effects didn't stand out too much. There were some underexposed moments, some grainy film. DVD transfer was pretty darn good. There was only one moment where color banding showed up, a very dark lantern scene outside into a snow storm. Some of the editing pace was off a bit here or there, nothing major, but a few scenes could have been tightened up.The special effects were not over the top, maybe they were a bit too muted in some regard. The whole abandoned inn was sort of covered with drippy stains running down walls. Where there were blood stains, they looked a lot like the other stains. When people died, there weren't blood splatters everywhere, unlike US slasher films. Given the extreme CSI the American public has been exposed to, we kind of expect a bit more realistic blood splattering now.As has been mentioned, this isn't a drive in jiggle movie. There is no nudity. The F word gets translated (well it's pretty clear they said that in Norwegian because the word sure sounds like the English word) several times, forcing this to an R rating. My guess, if there hadn't been two or three uses of that word, the MPAA would have rated this PG-13. This film, along with none of the slasher films is appropriate for that audience, no matter what the MPAA says. The right audience is older.In general, this was a good movie. If you like slasher films, and you want to think a little bit, and work to read the subtitles while watching, I think you will be rewarded watching this film. The ending leaves it up to the viewer to decide why the evil person kills people that go to this abandoned inn.Where this film moves beyond standard horror films is on the DVD and the special features. We've all grown tired of the same old dribble - the gag reel with everyone laughing at not funny mess ups, the making of featurette where the actors all retell the story (either ruining the story for you or blugeoning you with repitition), and the deleted scenes where the director tells you how much he loved this or that scene but had to cut it for pacing ----- yada yada yada. Nope Cold Prey does something much better.DVD Special Features (in the order they appear on the DVD):Alternate Ending - they ran out of money and time and the director shows a storyboard version of what they wanted to do. The ending they used was fine.Behind Cold Prey - somewhat similar to the making of featurettes, but with really good cast interviews and some views of how the film was shot.The Visual FX of Cold Prey - this is the motherlode of special features. If you want to better understand how a film is made and develops, there's four subtopics here that describe what CG effects were used (my favorite "in this scene there was some frozen dog pooh, so we got rid of it"); how color was used to set mood; an interview with the sound editor; and the iterations for making the poster / DVD cover art.Car Scenes - the director talks through the evolution from initial reading through final cut of the conversation in the car on the way to the mountain.Bloopers - not a series of stupid laughing, real live mistakes they made.Two Short films:Mountain Rose Runs Amouk - skip it 3 minutes of stupidity.An Evening in the Green - worth every second of the 4 minutes to watch.Music Video - decent, the music is good, the video is decent.Then a whole series of trailers, teasers, and TV spots for the film as shown in Norway.Overall, this is a good film. It's hard to imagine that it will be extremely successful in the US. Subtitles and horror films just don't usually work together. Of the genre, this one strikes a good balance of scaring and being a bit more intelligent. The director asked the sound man to make the audience be exhausted after watching this film. I was a bit tired, but not exhausted.
summary: Intelligent Slasher Film - Excellent Bonus Features

reviewText: Do you remember all of the great slasher flicks that came out in the early 1980's. The Reagan years spawned a huge crop of flicks along the lines of "Terror Train", "Madman", "Don't Go In The Woods....Alone!", "Slaughter High" and so many more. (If you don't remember those titles..just wait...Hollywood seems intent on remaking most of the 80's flicks these days and it's just a matter of time before the new versions come out)."Cold Prey" is a nifty little Norwegian slasher film along those lines. Unlike most of the recent slashers coming out of Hollywood, "Cold Prey" doesn't come across as a "Scream"-like parody of the genre. It doesn't try to be more than a slasher flick, there aren't any goofy twists that you have to keep an eye out for. It doesn't wollow in gore simply to show the latest and greatest in special effects, it basically follows the horror tenants set forth in flicks like "Prom Night" & "Happy Birthday to Me". 5 friends set out on a ski holiday, stumble into a psychopath's lair and become his next targets. "Cold Prey" even uses the same, now-cliched characters so familiar to horror film fans, The Jock, The Good Girl, The Dork and The Lovers. And while the characters are basically your standard horror film slaughter fodder, they aren't too annoying to where you are actually rooting for the killer.As a long time fan of slasher flicks, it was refreshing to see an old school horror film. While there isn't a ton of gore, what is shown is done well, and without CGI. You get the good old red-corn-syrup meets latex effects. The killer is quite impressive, and though his backstory seems a little muddled, he strikes a pretty impressive and scary figure making his way through the snow. I guess the only reason I don't rate this as a 5 star slasher is that the killer appears a little late in the film, and unfortunately, the five friends make up the entire potential victims list, so most of the killing doesn't really start until about 45 minutes into the film. I always like when they throw in a bonus body or two just to keep interest while waiting for the real action to begin. But, even with those personal taste issues, I love that "Cold Prey" is a back-to-basics horror flick...and well worth finding if you enjoy the genre.
summary: A Modern Slasher done in 1980's Style

reviewText: "Cold Prey" is a story about five Norwegian friends who decide to go skiing and snowboarding off the beaten path. While performing some stunts one of them breaks a leg. Instead of trying to hike back to their car, which is to far away to get to before nightfall, they see an abandoned ski lodge and decide to take shelter for the night. At this point it's nice to see that some things are universal. Anyone who watches an American made horror movie can easily tell you what will happen to one, if not more of them once they enter the show lodge. It seems in Norway they have to same idea.When reading the product description I was expecting "Cold Prey" to break new ground on the trapped teens - homicidal maniac slasher genre. Sadly it doesn't. It actually used a lot of the same set ups and tension building cliches that you would expect to find in any American made horror movie.Don't take that to mean I didn't enjoy the movie. I actually found it very enjoyable. I was especially thrilled to see that this wasn't a torture porn type of movie like "Saw" or "Hostel". Most of the kills worked on the idea of you know what's going to happen, so why do you need to see all the gory details. This is probably the result of a cultural difference between Europe and the US. It seems to me that Europeans tend to like their movies a little less violent than us Americans. Which I think works in this movies favor.Of course I didn't like everything about the movie. I think one problem problem a lot of movies have is they think they need to have a big twist. One that will wash over you like an epiphany. "Cold Prey" first gives you a hint that there's going to be a twist at the beginning of the movie when a young boy is being chased and apparently buried in snow. It then fades news reports talking about the disappearance of random skiers through the years. From that moment on you know that there has to be a big reveal to tie those two things to the story of the five friends.Without trying to give anything away, you should have a good idea of who the killer is by the end of the movie. What you won't be expecting is the so called twist that explains what turned him into a psycho killer. I was actually disappointed in the reveal. To me it didn't explain anything.One final thing that I didn't care for was the muted colors. It just made everything too monochromatic. All the colors were deadened to the point that they became indistinguishable from each other. When two of the characters are exploring the lodge they find a room that caught on fire sometime in the past. It was just too hard to tell the difference between the color of the burnt door to the unburnt ones. When go into the room, there just seemed to be no difference between the burnt walls and the ones from out in the hallway that had not been burnt. I'm okay with directors and cinematographers using muted colors, it just needed to be done with a lighter hand.The biggest concern I had was actually something I didn't need to worry about. I was concerned about watching a horror movie with subtitles. I was afraid that once the action picked up I might miss some of what was being said. Thankfully that wasn't a problem. I was able to keep up with the subtitles and focus on what was happening.I would definitely recommend this movie. Especially if you like movies like the original "Friday the 13th" before Jason became the killer or "Hostel" then by all means get it. It's going to be a little less violent that American made slasher films, but like I said I think that's a plus. Sometimes it's nice to see something that's going to work more on suspense and tension. We don't need all the blood and gore that has become prevalent in horror movies made today.
summary: A Great Change From the Usual Slasher Flick

reviewText: Cold Prey is a slick little slasher "that has terrified audiences around the world and put the edge back into the body-count genre"... or so says the back of the DVD case.  In actuality though, this Norwegian thriller is like so many other offerings from the slasher genre that you spend more time shouting what's going to happen next at the screen than being frightened-- probably not what the director intended(although he did do enough to get a release from Anchor Bay in the U.S. so...).  Cold Prey follows a group of 5 snowboarders who want more from their weekend than the tame and overcrowded ski lodges and slopes that the rest of the country will be enjoying, so they head out to a deserted mountaintop range made of "killer powder to shred(or something along those lines)."  As is apt to happen on these far off getaways, the dopey character of the gang breaks his leg and not only ruins their weekend, but starts the ball rolling on everyone's certain demise.  Miles away from civilization and in need of shelter from an approaching storm, they luckily come upon what looks to be an abandoned snow lodge to spend the night... "except somebody - or something - already lives there(again, quoted from the back of the DVD-- even I'm not THAT corny... most of the time)."  Cold Prey is well directed, with a great use of dreary lighting and muted color, some solid tension, and a fairly likable cast... but it's also icredibly cliche, sports a nearly bloodless body count of 4, and has a mysterious killer that even a novice of the genre can figure out from a mile away.  Being a devoted fan of slasher cinema, I've seen enough of these beauties to know that you can do far worse than this-- but also know that there are much better out there as well(especially if you prefer gore, lots of bodies piling up, nudity, and a general level of sleaze that this film never even makes an attempt at).  In closing I'll just say that Cold Prey does nothing new for the genre, and has far more in common with the slashers of the late 90's(i.e. I Know What You Did Last Summer, Urban Legend, and Scream without the cleverness) than it does with Halloween, Friday The 13th, and Black Christmas(the originals, NOT the Hollywood remakes!)... worth a watch, go in with low enough expectations and it might even impress(2.5 stars).
summary: A slasher throwback... but only to the late 90's I'm afraid(2.5 stars)

reviewText: Gang of semi-to-very attractive teens/twentysomethings + remote mountain lodge = slasher flick.And the Norwegian horror movie "Cold Prey" doesn't really deviate from what has worked for many other such movies. Fortunately some solid acting and some lovely stylistic flourishes add a unique look to this movie, but in the end it's neither more nor less than it appears -- a maniac in an old house, pickaxing people to death.Five twentysomethings have come to the ultimate mountain for some snowboarding and skiing... until Morten Tobias (Rolf Kristian Larsen) breaks his leg two minutes in. The only shelter is a long-abandoned mountain lodge, which also has a convenient stash of food and booze. They drink, party and make out that evening, since they can't get back to the car before morning.You can guess what happens next: After backing off on sex with Mikal (Endre Martin Midtstigen), Ingunn (Viktoria Winge) is horribly pickaxed to death, and Eirik (Tomas Alf Larsen) is caught on his way back. And Mikal and Jannicke (Ingrid Bols Berdal) finally uncover the facts -- there's a deranged maniac living in the lodge, and he's been killing everyone who comes there (and apparently taking their wedding rings).As a slasher flick, "Cold Prey" is fairly tame -- the goriest and most horrific stuff comes when director Roar Uthaug keeps pointing the camera at Morten Tobias' horribly fractured leg (complete with "SUPER GLUE?!" shots). And the whole movie simply drips with atmosphere -- grimy shadowy basements, pale dreary light, cold concrete hallways.It kind of makes up for the fact that the plot is strictly A-to-B, with the assorted people getting picked off one by one by the Evil Masked Killer and running frantically around the house. Uthaug lovingly splashes the sets with gouts of blood and pickaxes coming out of nowhere, and a masked killer who grunts and swings indiscriminately.But there are a few moments where it rises above the genre -- the characters are smart enough to barricade themselves in a room, and one of the more gruesome killings is paired (oddly enough) with bittersweet, vaguely religious music. And the adrenaline-charged climax atop an icy crevasse (with one of the characters waking underneath a pile of corpses) is nice work indeed.The actors all do very nice work -- Midtstigen does an excellent impression of a guy in shock, Winge has a brilliant final scene, and Larsen is excellent as the dork with unexpected courage. Berdal has some problems with looking horrified/terrified (she looks like she's trying not to laugh, actually), but is quite good when required to be a hardcore fighter or the mature, sensible one.And I'll say this -- Uthaug comes up with a very realistic slasher villain. Rune Melby appears in about one minute of the whole movie, but his bewildered eyes and body language say it all."Cold Prey" is your basic slasher movie -- albeit in Norwegian -- but it does have some nice moments that set it apart from the pack.

reviewText: Despite the packaging and reviews proclaiming its unusualness, "Cold Prey" is fairly formula bound, and can, at times, be predictable to anyone familiar with the genre.  That said, it is a visually arresting movie, not shot in typical horror style, with an unusually keen use of light and, particularly for a horror film, is stunningly photographed.  While I had the usual groans in certain spots, they were relieved almost instantly by the sharp imagery and director Roar Uthaug's cool, cool style.  The view from the mountaintop of Jotunheimen is never less than breathtaking, and the abandoned resort that serves as setting for the bulk of the film is nearly as much a character as The Overlook was in King (and ultimately Kubrick's) classic, The Shining.  The inn seems at first somewhat generic, but as we explore various rooms and wings - and parts we shouldn't - it seems to possess a life of its own, adding greatly to a film already dependent more upon atmosphere than storytelling.The cast of young actors is appealing - far more so than some of their characters, and each of them transitions nicely from carefree youth to doomed soul.It ain't perfect, and I've probably being unduly hard on it - but I was expecting something greater, bigger due to the hype surrounding the flick.  Nonetheless, it had me jump out of my skin at least once, and these days, that's no small feat.  Also, the soundtrack is terrific and again, the film really does look great.

reviewText: I promise you, no plot spoilers.Let me review the DVD package for "Cold Prey"(a.k.a. "Fritt Vilt"), a Norwegian horror film released in America by Anchor Bay.  As usual, Anchor Bay's presentation is superb.  It is presented in its theatrical widescreen aspect ratio of 2.35:1.  The picture and audio quality are great.  The package has numerous extras:"Alternate Ending."  The actual, proposed ending would have been more exciting.  Unfortunately, because of budget constraints, it couldn't be completely filmed.  The storyboard (black and white sketches) depict how the ending was originally conceived.  This is an interesting extra."Behind Cold Prey."  Short documentary, headed by director Roar Uthaug, detailing how the film was shot on location in the picturesque mountains of Jutenheimen, Norway.  The cast and crew actually lived in the close confines of the sets.  The wind and snow provided problems in shooting.  Interviews are provided by the lead actors, especially Ingrid Bolso Berdal, in the starring role of heroine, Jannicke.  The director claims the death scenes were the most enjoyable to film.  Indeed, these scenes, along with many others in the film, were extremely physical for the young stars who did a tremendous amount of running and jumping inside the hallways of the abandoned ski lodge and in the freezing snow.  Overall, this documentary was quite educational."The Visual FX of Cold Prey."  This feature is broken up into four parts, all of which are educational and interesting:a.  "Digital Effects" dealt with the enhancement of scenes to make them more terrifying.  For example, blood and flying wood chips were digitally added after a scene was shot.  Also, cabins, tourists, dog feces, etc., were often digitally erased when they got in the way during the filming of a scene.b.  "Color Grading."  Throughout most of the scenes, the colors were toned down to give the film a dark, dismal, depressing feel.  It almost looks like black and white.  It reminded me of the horror film "Wind Chill," which takes place on Christmas Eve on a haunted highway in the mountains.c.  "Sound Design."  Death scenes were enhanced with terrifying sounds.  Fruits and vegetables were used for sound effects.  For example, the breaking of a spine was accomplished by snapping celery sticks.d.  "Poster Design."  This montage showed how the final poster evolved from a series of rejects."Car Scenes" depicts various rehearsals of the film's beginning until the actual scene was shot.  There is quite a bit of clowning around from the lead actors.  This extra is not very interesting in my opinion."Bloopers."  This is a long, boring sequence of outtakes where the stars messed up their lines.  I honestly didn't find it enjoyable."Short Film:  Mountain Rose Runs Amok."  This is a very strange, confusing story made up by the stars.  It doesn't have anything to do with the film itself.  The actors, it seemed, were bored.  This short film is not worth watching."Short Film:  An Evening in the Green."  Director Roar Uthaug's first homemade film, which is strange and gory.  A young business man is run over by his lawnmower and chopped to pieces.  It is worth watching once.Music Video.  Bloodlights sings an entertaining rock song titled "One Eye Open."  It is highly appropriate for the film.A teaser trailer, a theatrical trailer, and two television spots round out the extras and they are all good.A replica of the movie poster is inside the DVD keep case!!As for the film itself, "Cold Prey" is very gory, suspenseful and horrifying.  It is very reminiscent of such modern horror films as "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre," "Wrong Turn," and "House of Wax."  They all involve serial killers who've been causing the disappearances of countless tourists.In "Cold Prey," five friends are snowboarding.  One of them suffers a compound fracture.  They seek shelter in an abandoned ski lodge.  Unfortunately, someone, or something, still lives there and they have a room full of metal chains and hooks hanging from the ceiling."Cold Prey," as some reviewers have noted, does resemble the classic horror films "Halloween" and "Friday the 13th."  It also reminded me of "Hell Night," in which a group of fraternity and sorority pledges are locked in an abandoned manor; however, a deranged mongoloid still lives there.  Another movie that "Cold Prey" reminded me of is "Shredder" - an American film released in 2003.  A group of snowboarders break into an abandoned ski lodges and are killed by someone in a fur parka.  Also check out "The Shining" if you are into abandoned lodges at wintertime.A claustrophobic chiller, "Cold Prey" is highly recommended for fans of suspenseful slasher flicks.  It is perfect late night viewing on a cold winter's night.  Furthermore, it is always interesting to see what Europe is releasing in regards to the horror genre.
summary: Blood Splatters And Woodchips Fly As An Axe Wielding Maniac Slaughters Teens In An Abandoned Ski Lodge

reviewText: Cold Prey really isn't my type of movie. I enjoy a good horror flick every now and then but the standard "slasher" movie just doesn't do it for me. If you enjoy this kind of thing then you may be in for a treat, because Cold Prey has some good things going for it. The basic premise is as follows: 5 friends on a snowboarding trip are forced to stay in an abandoned (or is it?) cabin for the night, but guess what...they're not alone. reviewText: What exactly can I say about FRITT VILT (COLD PREY) that hasn't been said already. Well lets start here... In a world overdosed on allegedly scary slasher movies this Norwegian film truly harks back to the darkest roots of the genre and delivers a film that manages to maintain a terrifying atmosphere with genuine suspense.It's an old and tried storyline: Take five teenagers, place them in an eerie isolated location with little hope of escape (this being a long abandoned mountain-top hotel during a blizzard) and add an extremely violent killer to stalk them inside.However, what differentiates FRITT VILT from the rest of the pack is it's sharp direction by Roar Uthaug who manages to keep the same old clichés of the genre interesting. He does this mainly through the characters. Here we have five close friends who emote a sincere fondness for each other and for this reason alone we grow to like them. Unlike most other slasher movies where the majority of characters are simply used as a tool to increase the body-count and showcase gory effects these characters propel the story along and all have a purpose within the movie that serves the plot very well. As a result when we watch them die it becomes upsetting and genuinely disturbing. In particular the first murder is increasingly harrowing and while watching it I felt an overwhelming pity for the person involved.Another reason it succeeds is the fluid cinematography by Daniel Voldheim who paints each shot with atmospheric lighting and shadow so the darker scenes generate true claustrophobia and tension. The soundtrack by Magnus Beite is wonderfully haunting, moving and terrifying while the performances by all involved are incredibly accurate, particularly Ingrid Bolso Berdal as Jannicke who provides a compassionate heroine whom we quickly grow to love and in the climax we truly feel her anguish and pain.This is an outstanding movie within the slasher genre and a sterling example of Norwegian horror. In the tradition of the original "Halloween"  and "Friday the 13th", "Cold Prey" is destined to become a classic.
summary: Serious SLASHER returns the genre to it's scariest roots

reviewText: The one thing that makes producing a slasher film so difficult is avoiding becoming just another horror film.  Since the genius of Wes Craven we've seen all kinds of wannabes try to make horror films that try to be original but just became another movie (Dr. Giggles comes to mind).  The SAW franchise took this to a new level with having gratuitous violence for the sake of doing so and, has since, become a powerhouse franchise.  Similar to the following of Wes Craven, a group of wannabes were spawned.  They didn't even try to come up with new stories or anything truly original, they just wanted to see who could make the audience the most sick.Enter Cold Prey.Cold Prey marketed itself exclusively as a slasher film breaking the chain of generic slasher films with a mixture of suspense and an exciting plot twist one did not expect.  Everyone, and I do mean everyone, was raving about this film and how it was not like the other slasher films out there.  I honestly hoped the Europeans finally came up with a solution for cookie-cutter slasher films but, alas, they only perpetuated the cycle of mass produced hack and slash films albeit under the hype of being different.It follows the exact same formula as other slasher films; teens go try something different because they're hardcore, teens don't factor other obvious factors (in this case, injury and no cell phone coverage) and need to seek shelter, seek shelter in seemingly benign building, building currently occupied by bad guy, teens have moments of relaxation, teens slowly die one by one, showdown, plit twist, weird ending.  That's Cold Prey in a nut shell without *chuckle* spoiling the plot twist, which I figured out literally in the first minute of the film.The only elements that were fairly unpredictable were who dies in what order.  This gives the film it's only plus as it gives the audience a great opportunity to taunt the slasher for not killing the preferred victim first.  I'll admit my brother and I were cheering on the slasher as we didn't feel, at all, sorry for most of the victims save for the one "virgin" character.  Otherwise, we had on our foam fingers and were rooting for the bad guy ("Go slasher go!").So, in all, the story was OK at best. reviewText: Director Roar Uthaug's COLD PREY is is a truly terrifying horror film that hearkens back to 1980s-era slasher flicks.  What makes the film so unique--at least for American audiences--is that it was shot in Norway by a Norwegian crew and features an all-Norwegian cast.  But if the fresh talent and fresh faces aren't enough, the film offers a tightly plotted story that adds a new twist to the old slasher formula.  It basically transplants FRIDAY THE 13TH from the abandoned summer camp at Crystal Lake to an abandoned ski lodge in the frozen, snow-packed mountains of northern Europe.  Another fresh twist to the formula is that even the virginal kids get whacked, and the true identity of the killer, while not a total surprise when revealed at the end, makes him a more sympathetic character than genre icons Jason or Michael.The acting in COLD PREY is outstanding--if you watch with the original Norwegian soundtrack, that is; the English dub is...well...a dub--and Norwegian beauty Ingrid Bols Berdal is especially effective in her tough-but-sympathetic portrayal of the film's obligatory final girl.  Roar Uthaug's direction is also top-notch--he's definitely a Euro-horror director to keep your eye on--and the special FX are seamless and realistic yet eye-poppingly fun.  As with the '80s slashers to which COLD PREY plays tribute, a lot of the really gruesome violence is off-screen (the camera cuts away just after contact), but that's part of the fun.  The only real flaw in the film is that there isn't a single T or A shot--and the film's two beauties would be worth seeing sans clothing, even if only in a quick cutaway--which has been a must-have part of the genre since John Carpenter's HALLOWEEN (1978), but that's only a minor gripe.The DVD edition of COLD PREY from Anchor Bay is well worth the price of admission.  It features a beautiful digital transfer of the film in anamorphic widescreen at its original aspect ratio of 2.35:1, with  soundtracks offering either the original Norwegian in DD 5.1 Surround Sound or an English dub in DD 2.0 Surround.  Tons of bonus features include a behind-the-scenes featurette, a featurette on the special FX, interviews with the cast, and much more!COLD PREY has lots of jumps and scares, and the story is several notches above a lot of slasher fare.  If you're a fan of old 1980s slasher flicks and would like a break from the torture-porn that seems to have taken control of the horror screens these days, give this film a screening.  You won't be sorry.

reviewText: Originally made in 2006, Fritt vilt, or Cold Prey as it is known outside of Norway, is one of those few forgein horror gems that every so often you may stumble across, and thanks to the good folks at Anchor Bay, it has finally made its way here. The story revolves around a group of friends looking to enjoy some snowboarding action, only to have one of the group get injured.  They find shelter in what appears to be an abandoned ski lodge, which just so happens to be inhabited by a hulking killer.  Soon enough, they are stalked and picked off, culminating in a snowy showdown.  While it isn't quite as bloody as gorehounds may hope, Cold Prey relies on some well orchestrated suspense to keep you glued to the screen.  The script is intelligent, and there's actually character development (in a slasher flick? Egads!) to be found as well.  The DVD itself is worth noting, and is packed with an assortment of extras including two short films, trailers, a blooper reel, an alternate ending, a music video, and various featurettes on the making of the film and the visual FX.  All in all, Cold Prey is a compelling, suspenseful slasher that is more than worthy of your time.  Now let's hope that it doesn't take two years for Anchor Bay to bring Cold Prey 2 over to our shores.

reviewText: This Norwegian horror film is apparently a success in Europe. The taglines and marketing claim it's "the most perfect slasher movie ever made".  To that I say, "rubbish.""Cold Prey" is yet another maniac-killer-of-teens film featuring a group of 5 young people (male & female, a little older than teens but certainly not over 24) off on a ski excursion out in the Norwegian mountains.  In typical slasher film fashion, they're all incredibly stupid.  For one thing, they pick a spot far away from civilization in a dangerous remote location where (of course) their cell phones don't work.  One kid breaks his leg, so instead of going for help in their CAR, they spot an abandoned resort-hotel (out in the middle of nowhere??) and decide to hang out there until the next morning. Did I say the kid has a compound fracture?  Hello?  Anyway, the hotel has been closed for 30 years but there are some sinister/creepy things about it that WE see as soon as they go inside.  They're too stupid to notice because they're too busy laughing, ready to party, despite the one kid's leg.  Of course, they do all the cliches like split up, go exploring...one couple pairs up and finds a room together, etc.  And yep, there's a slasher maniac that lives in the basement (or in the shed, it's not really clear).  He starts picking them off one by one, just like in Friday the 13th or any other teen slasher movie.There are the usual I-can't-believe-they're-so-dumb situations like someone turning up music on the stereo so loud that they can't hear the screams in another part of the hotel; people running and tripping just as the killer is upon them; and basically no one doing anything really smart.  At one point a kid is running from slasher, darts into a room where the others are hiding, and proceeds to frantically barricade the door without telling his friends that the guy is coming.  They're asking, "What's wrong? What's the matter?" and all the kid does is say, "Shut up! Help me! Shh!", instead of explaining, "He's coming, a killer is coming!"The filmmaking is pedestrian and uninspired.  There is too much reliance on sudden noises and jump-at-you moments to try and scare the audience.  In this day and age, that's just lazy. The movie is also bloody, unpleasant, and not much fun. When we finally get to the "big reveal" about who the killer is, it's such an undeveloped who-cares moment that we wonder why we've sat through this thing.There is nothing about this film I can recommend, except to hardcore fans of slasher films--*any* slasher films--even bad ones.

reviewText: I had some fairly high expectations for COLD PREY...okay, at least they were high for a "slasher" film.  I'd never heard of it, but when I received a copy, I did a little bit of research and saw that there was quite a bit of buzz around this Norwegian film.  It was supposed to revitalize the genre, or perfect it or at least exceed its limitations.I was sorry to see that it did none of these things.  It was a fairly standard "teenagers trapped in a secluded spot with a madman" story.  It wasn't particularly surprising, nor especially scary.  And it wasn't very gory.  (I wasn't expecting "torture porn" such as WOLF CREEK or SAW...but it was tame even by FRIDAY THE 13TH standards.)Five college-age buddies are on a snowboarding trip in Norway.  Rather than endure the crowds of a regular ski resort, they've been told about a really challenging run out in the middle of nowhere.  These early scenes are actually quite beautiful, if you like snowscapes.  The mountain scenery is quite imposing.  But naturally, one of their number, Marten...the goofball who doesn't have a girlfriend...crashes and suffers a rather serious leg break.  Jannika...the dark-haired, more serious of the two girls...fixes him up as best she can and they make their way to an old resort lodge off in the distance.  The place appears to have been deserted for decades, but they are able to make themselves at home and survive a night of typical slasher-movie banter and coupling.  Jannika is serious about Eirik, a handsome, hunky stolid type, and then we've got Ingunn, the blonde, and her new boyfriend Mikal...a less "serious" sort than Eirik.  While Jannika and Eirik stick with Marten who is confined to a sofa and still in pain...Ingunn and Mikal find themselves a room to be alone...always a mistake in slasher films.I won't tell you more of the plot, except to say that it unfolds more or less as you'd expect.  There is an axe-wielding, large, wrapped-in-a-fur-parka, silent mad man after them.  It takes awhile for them all to realize what's going on, and when reality sets in, the true natures of their personalities are revealed...some hold up to the scrutiny of pressure better than others.The movie is handsomely filmed in a russet and sepia toned way.  The gore is dialed down, which makes the film a bit more serious in tone.  We aren't cringing at the gore, and laughing at how much we're expected to believe.  COLD PREY takes itself seriously, and there is little winking irony which taints so many films of this type today.It's hard to judge the acting, because the cadences of Norwegian are unfamiliar to me...I expected it to be something like Swedish, which is not too far from German (a language I know fairly well)...but instead, it sounded not exactly like any language I knew.  But Ingrid Bolso Berdal as Jannika was a strong presence.  She emerges as the strength of the group, and builds a character with equal parts compassion and sinewy determination.  The other performers are fine as well...there's less of the overtly silly sexuality that one often has to endure with American films of this ilk.But there's nothing really new either.  It was a perfectly okay evening, but I let myself be suckered into expecting much more.  Set your expectations properly and you should still enjoy this well-made, tight but not very original film.  (At least you'll sound cool when you tell your friends you watched a Norwegian slasher movie.)

reviewText: "Cold Prey" is a Norwegian film with subtitles, but that should in no way deter you from experiencing this well-crafted horror flick.  Following in the tradition of American low-budget horror pictures, it features no name stars, follows a standard plot, and features episodic murders.  Incorporated is the tried-and-true theme of the horror of claustrophobia -- the movie is set in an abandoned resort, far from any possibility of outside intervention.  Several young people are trapped here and then are stalked by a killer.  Yes, a very familiar horror film ingredient, but handled extremely well by director Roar Uthaug.  The movie's greatest strength is its foreboding, creepy atmosphere, nicely sustained throughout.  So often, modern directors don't realize that suspense is a PRIME ingredient of a successful horror movie.  You won't be shortchanged in the suspense department with "Cold Prey."  This is a neat little horror film worth investigating.

reviewText: I have seen other reviews that have praised this movie, but I have to disagree.  This is a very standard, by-the-numbers, slasher movie with forgettable characters, plot, dialog, and setting.  Picture "Friday the 13th," only in abandoned lodge in the mountains of Norway and you'll have a pretty good idea of what you are going to see.  Oh, yeah, throw in a dose of "My Bloody Valentine" for good measures, keep that in mind too, or maybe, well, any other slasher movie, to be honest.I promise you that you will guess who the killer is REALLY early on in the movie.  The killer is telegraphed from the very start of the movie and I am absolutely certain that nobody will be surprised when the "big payoff" comes.Anyway, here's the basic plot:A group of youngsters go off on a snowboarding trip in the mountains and, as you might have guessed by now, are set upon by a killer when they find themselves holed up in an abandoned lodge after one of the kids breaks his leg.  The killer VERY slowly dispatches with his victims as they attempt to figure out the mystery of the guy who has, as it would seem, killed many others.  What is quite hard to understand is how he finds victims in this isolated, run down, abandoned lodge miles from any populated area.  The feeling of isolation the filmmakers attempted to create is ruined by the fact that the killer is supposed to have killed a lot of people, judging by the artifacts in his room.  The standards of the genre apply as the movie unfolds.I know that the director was trying to build suspense, but it didn't work, as he failed to make me feel anything for any of the characters.This is certainly not a movie that will satisfy gore lovers, as there are not many bloody shots.  It will also not satisfy fans of movies like "Hostel" or "Saw," as there isn't any really sadistic violence.  This movie attempts to be a 70s/80s-style slasher movie, but doesn't do it very well.  Overall I found the movie to be a standard, formulaic, movie that did not differentiate itself from really any other movie in the genre.The movie scored points with me, however, by using a song by the excellent Norwegian band Turbonegro in the ending credits.Overall: 3/5 (being generous)

reviewText: Cold Prey is a Norwegian-made slasher film that breaks no new ground, but is a competent and enjoyable entry into that genre.  This is a perfect example of the influence American horror films have worldwide.  Director Roar Uthaug has gotten in his hands on the slasher handbook and runs it play-by-play.  In this case, that's a pretty good thing.An opening montage of news stories reveals numerous disappearances of travelers in and around the Jotunheimen Moutains of Norway.  A group of five young friends takes to these mountains to go skiing and snowboarding.  When one of the men breaks his leg, the group finds an abandoned ski lodged and takes refuge from the snow and cold until they can seek help. They'll soon discover that they are not alone as a huge pick-wielding manic begins stalking the group.  With no way to call for help in the desolate mountain range, they have to fight for their lives to survive the madman.As mentioned, there's nothing new in Cold Prey that you have not seen in most slasher films other than the novelty of it being an all-Norwegian cast and Norwegian language film.  However, Director Roar Uthaug has a firm grasp of the genre.  He knows how to build tension slowly, and like the original Halloween, he doesn't go overboard with blood and gore.  Cold Prey is heavy with atmosphere as this stark, snow-covered mountainous landscape leaves little in the way of opportunity to escape.He even nails down the typical slasher film characters...there's the young couple who cannot keep their hands off each other(Mikal and Ingunn), the group jokester (Morten Tobias), and the courageous female heroine (Jannicke).  All standard stuff but deftly handled.  Ingrid Bols Berdal is particularly fun to watch as Jannicke.  The mountain scenery is beautiful and the film is technically superior to many recent American slasher films I've seen.  And just as predictable, a sequel has already been made, picking up where the first story left off.  One word of advice, watch the film in the original language with English subtitles, the dubbed version is laughably bad!

reviewText: Directed by Roar Ithaug, Cold Prey (Fritt Vilt)(2006), contains elements common to many slasher films, but unlike most in the genre, they fit together cohesively to produce a chilling  horror thriller, that is still  extremely effective, although the spoken language is Norwegian.The movie enjoys a unique setting, high on the snow covered slopes of a mountain, where a group of five college age friends are off on a snowboarding trip.  When one of them has an accident, it causes the group to seek refuge in an abandoned lodge.  The film successfully establishes a feeling of isolation, which draws the audience into the situation.  Color is used to help establish a mood, as the film has a desaturated look, usually with a light greenish tone.The story is uncomplicated, without a lot of distractions, and it becomes easy to identify with the characters, and almost feel that you are in the lodge with them.  While from another culture, the young people seem very real, normal, and likeable.  The injured man, Morten Tobias (Rolf Kristian Larsen), is an introspective type.  Mikal (Endre Martin Midtstigen) and Ingunn (Viktoria Winge) are a young love struck couple, while Jannicke (Ingrid Bolso Berdal) and Eirik (Tomas Alf Larsen) are a couple that have been together for a while, and are trying to sort out where their relationship is going.  Cut off from the outside world, but safe from the cold, the group is just settling in for the night, when a figure appears, and sinks his snow axe into soft human flesh.As the group explores the small lodge, the discover evidence that they are not alone, and soon encounter the killer, who is masked, dressed in a parka, and ready to use his axe.  Things take a little while to get going, serving to build up a little tension, but once the killer gets busy, matters proceed rapidly.  The action is non-stop, and the level suspense is sustained up until a chilling conclusion at the edge of a fissure in the ice.  That fact that Jannicke, is intelligent and takes decisive action, is one of the main reasons that the film flows so smoothly, and feels so real.  There is little wasted time, as even though terrified, the survivors do not panic or get hysterical.  Ingrid Bolso Berdal does a fabulous job, and Rolf Kristian Larsen, is also very good.  There are a few questionable story elements, but there are no major flaws, or wasted moments, in this well composed and executed horror chiller.The DVD contains some interesting bonus material related to the production of the film, including covering how the film was processed to adjust the color.  Director Roar Ithaug and his crew were isolated on location, when shooting parts of the film, where they could focus on what they were doing 24 hours a day, if necessary.Cold Prey launched the Norwegian slasher genre, and was followed by Cold Prey II (2008) which continues where the first film left off, featuring Jannicke and the snowman killer.  Cold Prey III is scheduled for release in the fall of 2010, and is reportedly a prequel, focusing on the early life of the mysterious killer.

reviewText: I have heard such great things about "Cold Prey", so when I saw this under amazon's "vine program", I immediately decided to pick it out. Also, known as "Fritt Vilt" in its native Norwegian roots, the film had very promising reviews in Europe (?) and has been referred to as "the most perfect slasher film ever made"--well, whoever, said those things about this film deserves a "Leopard Thrust" in the face.Five friends decide to go up the mountains for a little snowboarding. One of their number, Morten (Rolf Kristian Larsen) breaks his leg while doing some stunts and they end up taking shelter from a blizzard in an abandoned ski lodge until the storm breaks. The five friends try to make the most out of their problems, but unfortunately, they're not alone. A huge killer with a pick ax is bent on killing all of them--oh, did I mention the killer is wearing winter gear?Despite what the dvd back cover says, "Cold Prey" is just another "helplessly trapped by an insane killer" movie. The film does have some nice cinematography and the deserted ski lodge does exude somewhat of an intimidating and ominous atmosphere. The colors are intentionally muted to exude some creepiness and the acting is fairly decent. Well, Ingrid Bolso Bordal (who plays Jannicke) is actually the actress who steals the show, but unfortunately she was given so little to work with. The acting wasn't bad, but the film definitely carried too much obligatory dry dialogue.The problems with the film begins because it is so badly paced and needed a lot of editing, this film would have been better as a 60 minute movie. Nothing much happens, the time is all spent talking and walking around, and when the first victim is killed, it was almost so predictable and the kill scenes are almost bloodless with the bare minimum in violence. There are also a lot of wandering around and talking even after the killer's presence is known. Now this wouldn't be a bad thing if it managed to generate suspense, but sadly it doesn't. A slasher has to have an abundance of gore and blood--failing that maybe suspenseful elements might save the film. "Cold Prey" lacks two important aspects of a successful slasher. I buy into a bloodless kill, but every movie with these kind of elements has to have at least one memorable scene.To add another nail to its coffin, the main antagonist is very uninteresting. We see him committing obscene acts of murder, so what is the motivation? His past is partly revealed in the form of newspaper clippings but none of them seemed very believable. An angry killer with a bleak past which was revealed at the last act but it felt like a cheap attempt at a twist, which ended up as a throw-away detail. I also hoped for the best that our killer may be a cannibal, but his motivations is left to the viewers' perspective, and what he does with the bodies is just so--dull?Anyway, this film had some potential but none of them was realized. The film is a just a throwback from 90's slashers (thanks, amazon friend D-Willie!) . I thought maybe something got lost in translation since I watched this in its original language and maybe the English Subtitles were bad but I thought Anchor Bay would know how to release a good Dvd. Regardless, the film never gives any credible scares (I would've been happy with cheap ones) and thrills are virtually none-existent. I can excuse a plot with cliché, so long as the experience is thrilling, but now that I've seen "Cold Prey", the supposed movie "that left Europe screaming" may have been folks screaming to get their money back. (maybe Americans are just so used to slasher films?)Rent it [2 Stars=mediocre]Video/Audio: 2.35 anamorphic widescreen. Extremely sharp transfer with muted colors. Some grain on some scenes but I think they were intentional. The 5.1 Dolby Digital Norwegian track is quite powerful and clear.Extras: Two nifty short films, an alternate ending, Trailers, making of and behind the scenes/bloopers.
summary: "Cold Prey" is a Norwegian Slasher flick that Slowly Freezes!

reviewText: With the overwhelming amount of slasher movies being churned out these days it's hard to know what to expect when you sit down to watch a new one. I have to admit that with Cold Prey I wasn't expecting much at first. But when I found out that it was a Norwegian film I figured it had to be at least decent or it wouldn't have been subtitled and repackaged with an English title. And that's definitely the case.Cold Prey (or Fritt vilt, rather) is a classy slasher film - if such a thing can be said to exist. As expected with most slasher films, the setup is a bit thin - a group of friends decides to go snowboarding on a huge mountainside in the middle of nowhere. We get a few minutes of them flying dowthrough the snow before one of them has a bad accident, leaving him unable to climb back out of the valley they're now in. Luckily, the group finds an old abandoned hotel and decides to shack up there for the night and go for help in the morning. Obviously, this turns out to be a bad decision. There just happens to be someone (or something) in the hotel that doesn't want them there.And so the killing begins. But the filmmakers have been clever here. The pacing of the film is near-perfect, there's hardly a lull to be found and the dialogue is actually impressive (as compared to most slashers, at least). The actors deliver, especially Rolf Kristian Larsen as the injured Morten Tobias. The setting is reminiscent of The Shining, but there's not really much else to justify a comparison between the two movies - I'd say this is more like Halloween On Ice.There are a few twists of the plot, though most of it is pretty straightforward for anyone who knows the slasher format. But though I could guess 90% of the plot ahead of time, it was still fun to watch the execution (of the plot, that is... though the death scenes weren't bad either). This movie shows the potential that slasher films have and it's even good enough to make me want to see the already released sequel.
